results.title: It’s Election Season in Germany. No Charisma, Please!
results.abstract: The race to replace Chancellor Angela Merkel after 16 years in office is the tightest in years. But the two leading candidates are anything but exciting, and that’s how Germans like it.

multimedia.caption: Olaf Scholz, center left, of the Social Democrats, and Armin Laschet, center, of the Christian Democratic Union. Their race has become a contest to see who can best channel Chancellor Angela Merkel’s aura of stability and calm.

results.title: Gail Omvedt, 80, Dies; India Became Her Home, the Caste System Her Cause
results.abstract: An American-born sociologist, she moved to India in the 1970s, helped pioneer the study of castes and drew attention to the lives of the country’s most oppressed.

multimedia.caption: The scholar and activist Gail Omvedt in 1980 at a national conference on women’s rights in Bombay (later renamed Mumbai). She drew attention to members of an oppressed caste once commonly called the untouchables.

results.title: The New U.S. Challenge in Afghanistan: Coping With Taliban Rule
results.abstract: Its longtime enemy now a fact of life, Washington must choose when to shun or tolerate the group, with all the wrenching trade-offs each policy choice brings.
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: Historic London Synagogue Fights to Stay Out of the Shadows
results.abstract: The 320-year-old Bevis Marks Synagogue claims that two new proposed office towers would block its sunlight and add to the sense of enclosure amid the skyscrapers of the financial district.

multimedia.caption: Renovation work is visible outside the entrance of the Bevis Marks Synagogue in the City of London.
